column2: THE DRAGON-FLY CHILDREN AND THE SNAPPING TURTLE
column3: THE DRAGON FLY CHILDREN AND THE SNAPPING TURTLE

column2: The Dragon-Flies have always lived near the pond.
column3: The Dragon Flies have always lived near the pond.

column2: Not the same ones that are there now, of course, but the great-great-great-grandfathers of these.
column3: Not the same ones that are there now, of course, but the great great great grandfathers of these.

column2: A person would think that, after a family had lived so long in a place, all the neighbors would be fond of them, yet it is not so.
column3: A person would think that, after a family had lived so long in a place, all the neighbors would be fond of them, yet it is not so.

column2: The Dragon-Flies may be very good people--and even the Snapping Turtle says that they are--still, they are so peculiar that many of their neighbors do not like them at all.
column3: The Dragon Flies may be very good people-and even the Snapping Turtle says that they are-still, they are so peculiar that many of their neighbors do not like them at all.

column2: Even when they are only larvae, or babies, they are not good playmates, for they have such a bad habit of putting everything into their mouths.
column3: Even when they are only larvae, or babies, they are not good playmates, for they have such a bad habit of putting everything into their mouths.

column2: Indeed, the Stickleback Father once told the little Sticklebacks that they should not stir out of the nest, unless they would promise to keep away from the young Dragon-Flies.
column3: Indeed, the Stickleback Father once told the little Sticklebacks that they should not stir out of the nest, unless they would promise to keep away from the young Dragon Flies.

column2: The Stickleback Mothers said that it was all the fault of the Dragon-Fly Mothers.
column3: The Stickleback Mothers said that it was all the fault of the Dragon Fly Mothers.

column2: What can you expect, exclaimed one of them, "when Dragon-Fly eggs are so carelessly laid?
column3: What can you expect, exclaimed one of them, "when Dragon Fly eggs are so carelessly laid?

column2: I saw a Dragon-Fly Mother laying some only yesterday, and how do you suppose she did it?
column3: I saw a Dragon Fly Mother laying some only yesterday, and how do you suppose she did it?

column2: Just flew around in the sunshine and visited with her friends, and once in a while flew low enough to touch the water and drop one in.
column3: Just flew around in the sunshine and visited with her friends, and once in a while flew low enough to touch the water and drop one in.

column2: It is disgraceful!"
column3: It is disgraceful!"

column2: The Minnow Mothers did not think it was so much in the way the eggs were laid, "although," said one, "I always lay mine close together, instead of scattering them over the whole pond." They thought the trouble came from bad bringing up or no bringing up at all.
column3: The Minnow Mothers did not think it was so much in the way the eggs were laid, "although," said one, "I always lay mine close together, instead of scattering them over the whole pond." They thought the trouble came from bad bringing up or no bringing up at all.

column2: Now most of the larvae were turning into Nymphs, which are half-grown Dragon Flies.
column3: Now most of the larvae were turning into Nymphs, which are half grown Dragon Flies.

column2: They had been short and plump, and now they were longer and more slender, and there were little bunches on their shoulders where the wings were growing under their skin.
column3: They had been short and plump, and now they were longer and more slender, and there were little bunches on their shoulders where the wings were growing under their skin.

column2: They had outgrown their old skins a great many times, and had to wriggle out of them to be at all comfortable.
column3: They had outgrown their old skins a great many times, and had to wriggle out of them to be at all comfortable.

column2: Like most growing children, the Dragon-Fly larvae and Nymphs had to eat a great deal.
column3: Like most growing children, the Dragon Fly larvae and Nymphs had to eat a great deal.

column2: Their stomachs were as long as their bodies, and they were never really happy unless their stomachs were full.
column3: Their stomachs were as long as their bodies, and they were never really happy unless their stomachs were full.

column2: They always ate plain food and plenty of it, and they never ate between meals.
column3: They always ate plain food and plenty of it, and they never ate between meals.

column2: They had breakfast from the time they awakened in the morning until the sun was high in the sky, then they had dinner until the sun was low in the sky, and supper from that time until it grew dark and they went to sleep: but never a mouthful between meals, no matter how hungry they might be.
column3: They had breakfast from the time they awakened in the morning until the sun was high in the sky, then they had dinner until the sun was low in the sky, and supper from that time until it grew dark and they went to sleep: but never a mouthful between meals, no matter how hungry they might be.

column2: They were always slow children.
column3: They were always slow children.

column2: You would think that, with six legs apiece and three joints in each leg, they might walk quite fast, yet they never did.
column3: You would think that, with six legs apiece and three joints in each leg, they might walk quite fast, yet they never did.

column2: When they had to, they hurried in another way by taking a long leap through the water.
column3: When they had to, they hurried in another way by taking a long leap through the water.

column2: Of course they breathed water like their neighbors, the fishes and the Tadpoles.
column3: Of course they breathed water like their neighbors, the fishes and the Tadpoles.

column2: They did not breathe it into their mouths, or through gills, but took it in through some openings in the back part of their bodies.
column3: They did not breathe it into their mouths, or through gills, but took it in through some openings in the back part of their bodies.

column2: When they wanted to hurry, they breathed this water out so suddenly that it sent them quickly ahead.
column3: When they wanted to hurry, they breathed this water out so suddenly that it sent them quickly ahead.

column2: They all put their queer little three-cornered heads together, and there was an ugly look in their great staring eyes.
column3: They all put their queer little three cornered heads together, and there was an ugly look in their great staring eyes.

column2: Horrid old thing! said one larva.
column3: Horrid old thing! said one larva.

column2: I wish I could sting him.
column3: I wish I could sting him.

column2: Well, you can't, said a Nymph, turning towards him so suddenly that he leaped.
column3: Well, you can't, said a Nymph, turning towards him so suddenly that he leaped.

column2: She was often impatient, and said she could never go anywhere without one of the larvae tagging along.
column3: She was often impatient, and said she could never go anywhere without one of the larvae tagging along.

column2: I tell you what let's do, said another Nymph.
column3: I tell you what let's do, said another Nymph.

column2: Let's all go together to the shallow water where he suns himself, and let's all stand close to each other, and then, when he comes along, let's stick out our lips at him!
column3: Let's all go together to the shallow water where he suns himself, and let's all stand close to each other, and then, when he comes along, let's stick out our lips at him!

column2: Well, our lower lips anyway, answered the Nymph.
column3: Well, our lower lips anyway, answered the Nymph.

column2: Our upper lips are so small they don't matter.
column3: Our upper lips are so small they don't matter.

column2: We'll do it, exclaimed all the Dragon-Fly children, and they started together to walk on the pond-bottom to the shallow water.
column3: We'll do it, exclaimed all the Dragon Fly children, and they started together to walk on the pond bottom to the shallow water.

column2: They thought it would scare the Snapping Turtle dreadfully.
column3: They thought it would scare the Snapping Turtle dreadfully.

column2: They knew that whenever they stuck out their lower lips at the small fishes and bugs, they swam away as fast as they could.
column3: They knew that whenever they stuck out their lower lips at the small fishes and bugs, they swam away as fast as they could.

column2: The Giant Water-Bug (Belostoma), was the only bug who was not afraid of them when they made faces.
column3: The Giant Water Bug (Belostoma), was the only bug who was not afraid of them when they made faces.

column2: Indeed, the lower lip of a Dragon-Fly child might well frighten people, for it is fastened on a long, jointed, arm-like thing, and has pincers on it with which it catches and holds its food.
column3: Indeed, the lower lip of a Dragon Fly child might well frighten people, for it is fastened on a long, jointed, arm like thing, and has pincers on it with which it catches and holds its food.

column2: Most of the time, the Dragon-Fly child keeps the joint bent, and so holds his lip up to his face like a mask.
column3: Most of the time, the Dragon Fly child keeps the joint bent, and so holds his lip up to his face like a mask.

column2: But sometimes he straightens the joint and holds his lip out before him, and then its pincers catch hold of things.
column3: But sometimes he straightens the joint and holds his lip out before him, and then its pincers catch hold of things.

column2: When they reached the shallow water, the Dragon-Fly children stood close together, with the larvae in the middle and the Nymphs all around them. The Snapping Turtle was nowhere to be seen, so they had to wait.
column3: When they reached the shallow water, the Dragon Fly children stood close together, with the larvae in the middle and the Nymphs all around them. The Snapping Turtle was nowhere to be seen, so they had to wait.

column2: Aren't you scared? whispered one larva to another.
column3: Aren't you scared? whispered one larva to another.

column2: Scared?	Scared?
Dah!
column3: Dah!

column2: Who's afraid," answered he.
column3: Who's afraid," answered he.

column2: Oh, look! cried a Nymph.
column3: Oh, look! cried a Nymph.

column2: Just you wait until I change my skin once more, and then won't I have a good time!
column3: Just you wait until I change my skin once more, and then won't I have a good time!

column2: Sure enough, there he came through the shallow water, his wet back-shell partly out of it and shining in the sunlight.
column3: Sure enough, there he came through the shallow water, his wet back shell partly out of it and shining in the sunlight.

column2: He came straight toward the Dragon-Fly children, and they were glad to see that he did not look hungry.
column3: He came straight toward the Dragon Fly children, and they were glad to see that he did not look hungry.

column2: They thought he might be going to take a nap after his dinner. Then they all stood even closer together and stuck out their lower lips at him.
column3: They thought he might be going to take a nap after his dinner. Then they all stood even closer together and stuck out their lower lips at him.

column2: They thought he might run away when they did this.
column3: They thought he might run away when they did this.
